unnormalised: **Energy & Utilities News Snippet: Solar Rooftop Subsidies**
normalised: **Energy and Utilities News Snippet: Solar Rooftop Subsidies**

unnormalised: New Delhi – The Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE) has announced revised and enhanced subsidies for rooftop solar installations across India, effective immediately. Aimed at bolstering the "Solar for Every Home" initiative, the scheme provides significant financial assistance, particularly for residential consumers.
normalised: New Delhi – The Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (M N R E) has announced revised and enhanced subsidies for rooftop solar installations across India, effective immediately. Aimed at bolstering the "Solar for Every Home" initiative, the scheme provides significant financial assistance, particularly for residential consumers.

unnormalised: Under the updated guidelines, subsidies are tiered based on installed capacity. For systems up to 3kW, individual households can avail a subsidy of Rs. 18,000 per kW. For installations between 3kW and 10kW, the subsidy reduces to Rs. 9,000 per kW for the additional capacity. A cap of Rs. 1,17,000 per household is applicable.
normalised: Under the updated guidelines, subsidies are tiered based on installed capacity. For systems up to three kilowatt, individual households can avail a subsidy of rupee eighteen thousand per kilowatt. For installations between three kilowatt and ten kilowatt, the subsidy reduces to rupee nine thousand per kilowatt for the additional capacity. A cap of rupee one lakh seventeen thousand per household is applicable.

unnormalised: Dr. Anjali Sharma, Director of the Indian Renewable Energy Development Agency (IREDA), stated that these subsidies will make solar power more accessible, especially in Tier-II and Tier-III cities like Lucknow and Patna. The scheme also aims to benefit housing societies with rooftop areas exceeding 500 sq ft, promoting community adoption of solar energy. Discoms such as Tata Power Delhi Distribution Limited are geared up to facilitate the application process. The long-term goal is to achieve 40,000 MW of rooftop solar capacity by 2026.
normalised: Doctor Anjali Sharma, Director of the Indian Renewable Energy Development Agency (I R E D A), stated that these subsidies will make solar power more accessible, especially in Tier-Two and Tier-Three cities like Lucknow and Patna. The scheme also aims to benefit housing societies with rooftop areas exceeding five hundred square feet, promoting community adoption of solar energy. Discoms such as Tata Power Delhi Distribution Limited are geared up to facilitate the application process. The long-term goal is to achieve forty thousand megawatt of rooftop solar capacity by two thousand and twenty six.

unnormalised: Experts predict that these incentives will significantly lower electricity bills and contribute to a greener Diwali for Indian families.
normalised: Experts predict that these incentives will significantly lower electricity bills and contribute to a greener Diwali for Indian families.
